comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Aha! J is for John: (from www.stpatrickscathedral.org.au/bells/a-history-of-the-bel...) John Murphy was a Coppersmith of 14 Thomas Street Dublin who established his business in 1837. In 1843 he branched-out into bell founding, casting a bell for the Roman Catholic church in Tuam in County Galway. In the years that followed Murphy cast many single bells and at least eight rings of bells. Many of Murphy’s bells were thinner in profile than bells cast by other founders and intended for ringing, but that did not prevent Murphy bells being awarded prizes at the Dublin and London Exhibitions and First Prize in 1900 at the Paris Exhibition. John Murphy, who had founded the business, died in 1875. His son, John J. Murphy, then ran the foundry until it eventually closed. John J. died in 1948. In 1885 Matthew O’Byrne, who ran a foundry in James Street in Dublin, persuaded James Gaskin to join him. Gaskin had been the bell-maker at Murphy’s. Thereafter the Murphy Bell Foundry declined. According to Fred Dukes the last dated bell traceable to Murphy’s was cast in 1900.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Suspended Carol, suspended!  Bell casting was very skilled work.  Witness the Liberty Bell in the US which was cast in one of the oldest foundries in the world in Whitechapel in London.  The darned thing cracked and they mangled it trying to mend it over there.  John Murphy was a brave man to take on that work.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
"It's the way they toll them" as Frank Carson might have said.
I saw him a few times in Blackpool where his family lives. RIP Frank.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Consistently amazes me where these photos take us. In the past few weeks I was (coincidentally) doing doing some light research on a few addresses on Thomas Street. This included number 14 (where this bell was cast/recast). During 14 Thomas Street's past, it was: # A foundry (mid-19th Century). "John Murphy's Copper Works, Brass and Bell Foundry" cast several bells for the local and (intriguingly) Australian markets. # Home (in late-19th Century) to the "Dublin Pipers’ Club". Club members included noted nationalists - including Eamonn Ceannt (of Easter Rising note). # Headquarters (early-20th Century) to the 4th Battalion Dublin Brigade of the old IRA. It was named Arus Ceannt after the executed Ceannt. # Central (mid-20th Century) to the founding of "Comhaltas Ceoltóirí Éireann". A plaque at the address commemorates the fact!

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: FYI - There's an entry in the catalogue of the 1865 Dublin International Exhibition which puts Murphy's foundry was behind most of the notable bells hung suspended in Ireland. And beyond. (Christ Church, St Patricks, Limerick Cathedral, etc). Apparently there's an ad in Thom's 1962 Dublin Almanac and Directory - but I don't have access to a copy...

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: From an advert which appeared in Freeman's in December 1843 IRISH BELL FOUNDRY JOHN MURPHY, 137 JAMES'S STREET The great demand for Church Bells by the Catholic Clergy of Ireland, and the large sums of money sent out of the country for them, induced J. M. to make extensive arrangements for casting Church Bells - the only Church Bell foundry ever erected in Ireland - where the most recently invented improvements are introduced for the fusion and perfect amalgamation of the metals in a reverbatory furnace, heated by timber fuel, which gives the rich, mellow tones to these Bells. The successful result of this enterprise has defeated the anti-national traffic that imposed English Bells on ardent, patrioptic Irishmen, by the dextrous manoeuvre of calling Sale-rooms Bell Foundries and having the Salesman's name cast upon the English Bells. The complete advert can be seen here, including glowing testimonials from the Archbishop of Tuam and the Right Rev. Dr. John Cantwell, Bishop of Meath. By 1852 (now in Thomas St) he was announcing the export of his bells to Melbourne, Douglas (IoM), Warwickshire, Sunderland and King's Cross railway station, as a result of the medal awarded at the 1851 Great Exhibition in London. This proof of the superiority of the amalgam I use I expect will be sufficient to convince Irishmen that when I am supplying Bells to London and Birmingham, the very seat of metallurgic industry, even at high prices, that they cannot be mistaken where to deal for their Bells.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] I am also amazed at where these photos take us - the Australian bell mentioned in that 1867 letter went to St Francis Xavier's Cathedral, Adelaide , - "The bell used in the tower is the Murphy Bell of 1867, ... ". In those days everything iron including railway bridges was imported to Australia. Hear this bell (at about 2.55) - youtu.be/wB3d3KT_S3o bbooiiinngg! Sounds like a C# to me ...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] An idea from the other side of the world - the 'spire' and 'tuning fork' could be the stonework of the Entry Screen (with the terrace houses behind across Roden Place). The stonework has eroded badly and lost original bits and metal frills (frillyitus again?) over the years. Old photo - ringofgullion.com/graphics/dundalk/dundalk%20st%20patrick... Recent photo - www.flickr.com/photos/kilwirraarchitects/3074896680/in/se... Google Maps Street View - g.co/maps/s9mth

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Yes! There is a reverse view from the Entry Screen (see the stone cross centre bottom) of the blessing of the bells - catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000049602/Home .

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Well done! The spire, "tuning fork" and the faint building outlines in the background all make sense. You have also found the name of the Cardinal on the bell. Cardinal Logue was "the first archbishop of Armagh to be elevated to the College of Cardinals".
